sub_topic: Calculating the enthalpy and entropy of inorganic reactions
message_1:
Calculate the change in enthalpy and entropy for the reaction Mg(s) + 2HCl(aq) → MgCl2(aq) + H2(g) at 25°C given the following data:

- ΔH°f for MgCl2(aq) = -641.3 kJ/mol
- ΔS°f for MgCl2(aq) = -200.9 J/K/mol
- ΔH°f for H2(g) = 0 kJ/mol
- ΔS°f for H2(g) = 130.7 J/K/mol
- ΔH°f for HCl(aq) = -167 kJ/mol
- ΔS°f for HCl(aq) = -18.8 J/K/mol
- ΔH°f for Mg(s) = 0 kJ/mol
- ΔS°f for Mg(s) = 32.7 J/K/mol

Assume that ΔH°f and ΔS°f are independent of temperature.
message_2:
To calculate the change in enthalpy (ΔH) and entropy (ΔS) for the reaction, we will use the following equations:

ΔH = Σ ΔH°f(products) - Σ ΔH°f(reactants)
ΔS = Σ ΔS°f(products) - Σ ΔS°f(reactants)

For the reaction Mg(s) + 2HCl(aq) → MgCl2(aq) + H2(g), we have:

ΔH = [(-641.3 kJ/mol) + (0 kJ/mol)] - [(0 kJ/mol) + 2(-167 kJ/mol)]
ΔH = (-641.3 kJ/mol) - (-334 kJ/mol)
ΔH = -307.3 kJ/mol

ΔS = [(-200.9 J/K/mol) + (130.7 J/K/mol)] - [(32.7 J/K/mol) + 2(-18.8 J/K/mol)]
ΔS = (-70.2 J/K/mol) - (32.7 J/K/mol - 37.6 J/K/mol)
ΔS = -70.2 J/K/mol + 4.9 J/K/mol
ΔS = -65.3 J/K/mol

So, the change in enthalpy (ΔH) for the reaction is -307.3 kJ/mol, and the change in entropy (ΔS) is -65.3 J/K/mol at 25°C.
